title: Gravity Always Wins: A chronicle of 2024's space mishaps - DNA India
summary:
Gravity Always Wins: A chronicle of 2024's space mishaps

Publication Date & Source: January 2, 2025, DNA India

This article reflects on the various challenges and blunders that marked 2024's space exploration efforts, highlighting both serious issues and amusing mishaps along the way.

  • Florida Man's home struck by falling ISS debris
  • Japan's SLIM lander lands upside down but survives
  • IM-1 lander nicknamed “Odie” tops over after touchdown
  • Peregrine lunar lander fails shortly after launch
  • NASA cancels VIPER, intended for lunar polar exploration
  • Delayed opening of asteroid sample container by NASA
  • Boeing's Starliner causes astronauts to remain stranded on the ISS
  • SpaceX faces regulatory investigations and environmental concerns
  • Russia's missile test creates a massive crater instead of demonstrating its capabilities
  • Alien signal theory debunked when attributed to a truck's vibrations
“There was a loud noise,” Alejandro Otero said about the ISS debris incident, “and it almost hit my son.”

The article illustrates the unpredictable nature of space exploration, reminding us of the humor and humanity behind our attempts to conquer the final frontier.
newTitle: Gravity Always Wins: A Chronicle of 2024's Space Mishaps

summary:
2025’s First Meteor Shower 'Quadrantid' to Light Up the Skies: When to Watch in India

Published on: January 1, 2025   |   Source: Times of India

The Quadrantid meteor shower is set to be visible in India, with optimal viewing conditions allowing stargazers to witness this celestial event. The shower usually peaks in early January, providing a spectacular sight for astronomy enthusiasts.

  • The Quadrantids peak around January 3-4, 2025.
  • Best viewing conditions are expected from midnight to dawn.
  • Dark skies away from city lights are ideal for spotting the meteors.
  • This meteor shower can produce over 100 meteors per hour at its peak under perfect conditions.
“The Quadrantids are renowned for their bright fireballs and are a favorite among skywatchers.”

In conclusion, the Quadrantid meteor shower promises to be a must-see event for astronomy enthusiasts in India, offering a chance to witness one of the year's significant meteor displays.
newTitle: 2025’s First Meteor Shower 'Quadrantid': Viewing Guide for India

Four Lunar and Solar eclipses in 2025: Check dates, timings and visibility in Odisha - OTV News
summary:
Four Lunar and Solar Eclipses in 2025: Dates, Timings, and Visibility in Odisha

Publication Date: Not specified Source: OTV News

The year 2025 will feature four major eclipses, including two partial solar and two total lunar eclipses. Among these, only one total lunar eclipse will be visible from India.

  • The first total lunar eclipse is on March 14, not visible in India.
  • The first partial solar eclipse occurs on March 29, also not visible in India.
  • The notable lunar eclipse on September 7 will be fully observable from India, appearing blood-red.
  • The final partial solar eclipse will occur from September 21 to 22, not visible from India, focusing on Australia and Antarctica.
“The lunar eclipse on September 7 and 8 will be visible in India. It can be witnessed with the naked eye and will last for a long period, being visible until 12:22 AM.” - Suvendu Pattnaik

The upcoming eclipses present a unique opportunity for Indian observers, especially the September lunar eclipse, which promises a spectacular view.
newTitle: Four Lunar and Solar Eclipses in 2025: Dates, Timings, and Visibility in Odisha

Five Amazing Images of Nebula Captured by NASA Hubble Telescope

Date & Source: January 01, 2025, India.com

The NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope has provided us with a stunning collection of nebula images. These nebulae, located in distant galaxies, offer a glimpse into the cosmos.

  1. Veil Nebula: A small section of the Veil Nebula observed by Hubble.
  2. Eagle Nebula: A billowing tower of cold gas and dust rising from a stellar nursery in the Eagle Nebula.
  3. NGC 1501: A complex planetary nebula located in the constellation of Camelopardalis, showcased in a new image from Hubble's Wide Field Planetary Camera 2.
  4. Iris Nebula: A close-up of an area in the northwest region of the large Iris Nebula, clogged with cosmic dust.
  5. Lagoon Nebula: A colorful image of the Lagoon Nebula, captured to celebrate Hubble's 28th anniversary in space.

title: DNE reviews 10 groundbreaking scientific discoveries of 2024 - Daily News Egypt
NASA probe safely completes closest-ever approach to Sun - Kashmir Reader
summary:
NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Closest Approach to Sun

Date: 2022-12-30, Source: NASA

On December 24, NASA’s Parker Solar Probe successfully completed the closest-ever approach to the Sun, reaching a distance of 3.8 million miles (6.1 million kilometers) from the Sun's surface. The probe, traveling at speeds up to 430,000 mph (692,000 kph), endured temperatures up to 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit (982 degrees Celsius) in the Sun’s outer atmosphere, the corona.

  1. The Parker Solar Probe, launched in 2018, aims to study the Sun and help scientists understand why the Sun's outer atmosphere is hundreds of times hotter than its surface.
  2. The spacecraft uses gravity-assist flybys of Venus to inch closer to the Sun with each orbit.
  3. Data from the probe might help answer what drives the solar wind and better understand solar energetic particles.
“This mission allows us to get closer to the Sun than ever before, helping scientists understand how the solar wind forms, why the Sun’s outer layer heats up to millions of degrees, and how energetic particles accelerate near light speed.” - NASA

The Parker Solar Probe is expected to send detailed telemetry data about its latest journey on January 1.
newTitle: NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Closest Approach to Sun

summary:
The Future of Space Exploration: Robots vs. Humans

Date & Source: December 31, 2024. Source: TechSpot

Introduction: As robotic spacecraft achieve remarkable feats in extreme environments, scientists debate the future role of human astronauts in space exploration.

  • Robotic missions are cheaper than human spaceflight.
  • Advancements in AI could make robots more capable than humans in space.
  • Human-led missions provide national prestige and enable certain scientific research.
  • Some advocate for a balanced approach, combining human and robotic missions.
Lord Martin Rees, UK's Astronomer Royal: "Rapid advancements in robotics are reducing the need to send humans into space using 'taxpayer's money.'"

Conclusion: The future of space exploration may lie in a balance between human and robotic missions, each with its unique advantages and capabilities.
newTitle: The Future of Space Exploration: Robots vs. Humans

Warning Issued Over Imminent Danger of Kessler Syndrome Threatening Wi-Fi and Mobile Phones

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Not specified

Kessler Syndrome could disrupt communications by knocking out Wi-Fi and mobile phones due to increasing space junk.

  • Recent increases in space debris have raised alarms among experts.
  • Kessler Syndrome describes a catastrophic chain reaction of collisions in space.
  • Over 130 million pieces of space junk are currently orbiting Earth, with thousands of potential collision risks every day.
  • Experts warn that if action isn't taken, entire segments of the Earth’s orbital environment may become unusable.
  • The frequency of space launches has surged, increasing the risks associated with space debris.
Dan Baker stated, “Unless we do something, we are in imminent danger of making a whole part of our Earth environment unusable.”

The ongoing proliferation of space debris necessitates urgent intervention to mitigate potentially catastrophic risks to global communication systems.

title: How Artemis will land humans on the Moon - Astronomy Magazine
summary:
Artemis: NASA's Plan to Return Humans to the Moon

Date: 2024-12-15, Source: Astronomy Magazine

The Artemis program aims to return humans to the Moon by the end of the decade, marking the first time since the Apollo era. This article explores the history, key aspects, and challenges of the Artemis program, along with notable spacecraft and rockets involved.

History and Background

Sixty-five years ago, the USSR launched Luna 2, the first robotic mission to reach the Moon. The U.S. responded with the Apollo program, which resulted in the first human Moon landing. After a pause in lunar exploration, NASA is now working with international partners to resume human exploration of the Moon through the Artemis program.

Artemis Plan and Missions

  • Artemis 1: Uncrewed test flight of the Space Launch System (SLS) and Orion spacecraft, launched in 2022.
  • Artemis 2: Crewed mission to orbit the Moon using the SLS and Orion, tentatively scheduled for 2025.
  • Artemis 3: First crewed lunar landing since Apollo, using SpaceX's Starship HLS, planned for 2026 or later.
  • Artemis 4: Establishment of the Lunar Gateway space station, planned for 2028 or later.
  • Artemis 5: First use of Blue Origin's Blue Moon lander, planned for 2030 or later.

Challenges and Delays

The Artemis program faces technical challenges and delays, including issues with the Orion heat shield, spacesuit development, and the underperformance of SpaceX's Super Heavy rocket.

Notable Quotes

"As long as there is a national will to return to the Moon hand-in-hand with international partners, these obstacles can be overcome and more human footprints will join those left on the Moon half a century ago by the heroes of the Apollo era."

Image Caption: The Starship HLS stands like a giant 1950s science-fiction spaceship in this artist’s concept, spanning 30 feet (9 m) wide and reaching 160 feet (50 m) above the Moon’s surface. Credit: NASA
newTitle: Artemis: NASA's Plan to Return Humans to the Moon

summary:
Key Space Missions Planned for 2025: From Moon to Mercury

Publication Date: JANUARY 1, 2025

Source: The Jerusalem Post

2025 is shaping up to be a pivotal year for space exploration, with ambitious missions to the Moon and other celestial bodies planned by the United States, China, Japan, and the European Space Agency (ESA). These missions promise to advance scientific knowledge and inspire future generations to look to the stars.

  • NASA's Artemis program aims for human exploration of the Moon and Mars.
  • Blue Ghost Mission One will test technologies for lunar exploration.
  • SPHEREx will conduct a spectral survey of the sky.
  • China's Tianwen-2 will target asteroid Kamoʻoalewa for sample collection.
  • ESA's Space Rider will perform an orbital test flight.
  • JUICE will study Jupiter's icy moons after a Venus flyby.
  • Private companies like SpaceX and Intuitive Machines are contributing to lunar exploration.
"These missions promise to advance scientific knowledge and inspire future generations to look to the stars."

2025 is set to be a significant year for space exploration with multiple groundbreaking missions aimed at expanding our understanding of the universe.

After Ingenuity's success, Nasa introduces a new 'Mars Chopper' design - Business Standard
summary:
NASA Unveils New 'Mars Chopper' Design Following Ingenuity's Success

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: NASA News

Nasa has introduced a new helicopter design, the Mars Chopper, which is set to enhance Mars exploration after the success of its predecessor, Ingenuity.

  • The Mars Chopper is larger and equipped with six rotors, each with six smaller blades to increase lift.
  • It has a payload capacity of 5 kg, enabling it to carry scientific instruments for detailed terrain studies.
  • The helicopter demonstrates capabilities to reach distances of up to three kilometers.
  • It aims to assist in exploring areas that are inaccessible to rovers.
  • Ingenuity performed 72 flights over three years, far exceeding its initial mission requirements.
“Scientists could use Chopper to study large swaths of terrain in detail, quickly – including areas where rovers cannot safely travel.” - NASA

The Mars Chopper's advanced design is expected to significantly contribute to future missions, providing vital aerial data for both robotic and potential human explorations.
newTitle: NASA Unveils New 'Mars Chopper' Design Following Ingenuity's Success

Stargazers, assemble! List of astronomical events to grace our skies in 2025- Check details here - The Financial Express
summary:
Astounding Celestial Events to Look Forward to in 2025

Published: 2024-12-31, Source: Unknown (Based on Space.com reports)

The year 2025 promises an exciting lineup of astronomical events, sure to captivate stargazers worldwide.

  • Quadrantid meteor shower in January, visible from the West Coast of America, with up to 120 meteors per hour.
  • Moon moving in front of Pleiades Star Cluster on January 9, and again in February and July, best viewed through small telescopes or binoculars.
  • Venus's bright appearance in January and February, shifting to the morning sky by April.
  • Total lunar eclipse on March 13-14, visible across the Americas.
  • Saturn's ring disappearance from March 23 to May 6.
  • Partial solar eclipse on March 29, visible in parts of Africa, Greenland, and Europe.
  • Perseid meteor shower in the summer of August, accompanied by a close conjunction of Venus and Jupiter.

Article concludes with a list of remarkable celestial events happening in 2025, offering stargazers a wealth of astronomical spectacles to enjoy.
newTitle: Astronomical Highlights for 2025: Must-See Events for Stargazers

title: Alert! NASA Warns Of Massive Asteroid Racing Toward Earth Tomorrow At Over 74,500 KMPH - Times Now
summary:
NASA Warns of Massive Asteroid Approaching Earth Tomorrow at Over 74,500 KMPH

Date: January 1, 2025 | Source: NASA

NASA has issued a warning regarding asteroid 2024 YR9, which is expected to fly very close to Earth at speeds surpassing 74,500 km/h.

  • The asteroid is approximately 76 feet (23 meters) wide and categorized as an Apollo-type near-Earth object (NEO).
  • It will approach Earth on January 2, 2025, coming within 3.3 million km of the planet, which is a near miss in astronomical terms.
  • Despite the distance, if its trajectory were to change slightly, it could pose a serious threat due to its size.
  • Asteroids larger than 140 meters are deemed potentially hazardous, and this asteroid's proximity raises concerns.
  • NASA’s Planetary Defense is actively monitoring its trajectory using data from observatories worldwide.
“NASA is constantly monitoring such rocks in case of any future threatened collision with Earth.”

This incident underscores the importance of early detection in asteroid monitoring, allowing for potential preparations in case of an impending impact.
newTitle: NASA Warns of Massive Asteroid Approaching Earth Tomorrow at Over 74,500 KMPH

title: Astronomers reveal new insights into CIZA0107 Galaxy Cluster merger using VLA - India TV News
summary:
Astronomers Uncover New Details About CIZA0107 Galaxy Cluster Merger

Date Published: January 2025 Source: India TV News

An international team of astronomers has discovered exciting new details about a nearby galaxy cluster merger, providing a deeper understanding of galactic collisions.

  • The team studied the CIZA J0107.7+5408 galaxy cluster using the Very Large Array (VLA).
  • CIZA0107 is a post-core passage binary cluster merger, revealing new insights into cosmic ray acceleration and dark matter.
  • One major finding was diffuse radio emission spanning about 1.6 million light-years.
  • The spectral index of both subclusters was approximately -1.3, with significant disturbances along the merger axis.
  • These discoveries enhance comprehension of galaxy cluster mergers and their importance in cosmic evolution.
These findings contribute to a greater understanding of galaxy cluster mergers and their critical role in cosmic evolution.

The research on CIZA0107 not only enhances our knowledge about the universe but also sheds light on the complex dynamics of galaxy cluster interactions.
newTitle: Astronomers Uncover New Details About CIZA0107 Galaxy Cluster Merger
